Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Nicholas Craig von Sternberg of the University of Houston to conduct a research project in Engineering during the summer of 2013 at the Dynamic Systems and Control Laboratory of National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu, Taiwan. The project title is "Further Optimization of a Robot Inspired by Tai-Chi." The host scientist is Professor Ting-Jen Yeh.

The intellectual merit of this research lies within the research and development of a power-efficient walking robot. The applied power-saving technique, which was inspired by the ancient martial art of Tai-Chi, involves motion planning to use minimal actuation power to maintain balance at each point in the gait-cycle and disable unnecessary actuators. Further experimental analysis is being performed to determine additional power saving potential from the use of hybrid stepper motors and a custom controller in place of servomotors. This experiment is a result of the collaborative use of theory, hardware, and software developed by two geographically and culturally independent universities. The results of these projects could result in more power-efficient, environment friendly, walking robots with longer operation times; such robots could be used to increase the livelihood of the elderly or disabled, assist in tasks of daily life, or enter a hazardous situation in place of a human being.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As part of the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute, this project funding was awarded for a short-term collaboration between the principle investigator (PI) and a host University in Taiwan. For approximately two-months the PI joined researchers at the host university in their research toward the development of emissionless urban vehicles. Densely populated urban environments, such as the major cities of Taiwan, suffer from air pollution resulting from the gasoline combustion engine vehicles used for day to day transportation by the cities many inhabitants. The host university is developing several alternative modes of transportation including air-powered and electric motor powered vehicles to be used as future emissionless methods of transportation in these areas. The successful development and implementation of emissionless vehicles will have a direct impact on the quality of life of people living in urban environments since the air quality will be improved.

Most of the effort of this collaboration was put towards the development of a self-balancing unicycle which uses electric motors and a specialized control algorithm to provide emission free transportation for a single operator. Since space is another major concern of densely populated urban environments, the vehicle was designed to use only one wheel. Special control of the driving motor allows for balance of the device in the forward and backward direction. Another motor and mechanism is used for lateral balancing and steering. The motor is also controlled in a way that pedaling the unicycle can regenerate power without interrupting the balance. This vehicle would provide several benefits to society by reducing carbon emissions in the urban area, encouraging exercise during transportation since the unicycle can be pedaled to save power, and by reducing space occupied by transportation vehicles as the one wheeled vehicle is smaller vehicles with two or more wheels. This development is an ongoing project at the host institution.

The specific contribution of the PI during this short-term collaboration was the research, development, and implementation of wireless hardware and protocols to enable communication between devices. Such communication will enable the vehicles to be aware of eachother and even allow for the vehicles to be operated in tandem so that more than one ride could be transported. The current implementation provides for a master and slave vehicle and preliminary testing of tandem operation of two of the self-balanced unicycles will be performed pending modification of the control scheme to support such behavior.

In addition to the technical outcomes of this collaboration, the interaction between the individuals involved in this program produced many important outcomes. First of all the PI was immersed in the culture and society of the host country for approximately two months. This allowed for the exchange of ideas between the PI with other researchers, professors, students and local acquaintances. Living in this densely populated area gave the PI first hand experiences which imbued the importance of reducing emissions in such areas to improve quality of life and provided new areas and applications for future research. The personal interactions which occurred during this time brought forth a broad understanding and appreciation of cultural differences, but also unearthed many common thoughts and ideas which can make the world a smaller place. Personal interactions between the PI and members of the host institution created many new bonds which will provide inspiration and needed mentorship in both directions and created a solid foundation for future collaborations.
